title.narrative: Girls Education Challenge- Securing access and retention to good quality education

description.narrative: 1. To remove economic barriers that prevent girls marginalised by early marriage, domestic labour, risky child migration and/or street-living to enrol and stay longer in primary, secondary and/or vocational education. 2. To target marginalised girls who and support them to enrol in primary, secondary and/or vocation education learn useful knowledge and skills. 3. To support a creation of stimulating, safer, inclusive and child-friendly school learning environments for all girls and boys (including those with disability) in the 30 prioritised Kebeles. 4. To support increases in the value attached to girls' education by families of targeted marginalised girls (fathers and brothers especially) and their ability to develop more secure livelihoods to protect and support their daughters' education. 5. To support teachers, school administrators, parents groups, community leaders, community-based organisations and child protection structures to develop skills and mechanisms that will assure and sustain access of targeted marginalised girls into good quality education.

The project will support 15,053 extremely vulnerable girls aged 4-19 who are either not attending school or unable to thrive at school and do not receive stimulating or transformative education due to factors such as early marriage, child migration, sexual abuse and exploitation. They will instead access learning, knowledge and skills necessary to enable the realisation of their full-potential.

participating-org.narrative: Organisation for Child Development and Transformation (CHADET)

activity-date.narrative: Actual start date- Official start date of the project was 1st Feb 2013, however the first fund disbursement took place in March 2013

sector.narrative: Remove economic barriers that prevent girls marginalised by early marriage, domestic labour, risky child migration and/or street-living to enrol and stay longer in primary education. Targeted marginalised girls who are supported to enrol in primary education learn useful knowledge and skills.

Remove economic barriers that prevent girls marginalised by early marriage, domestic labour, risky child migration and/or street-living to enrol and stay longer in secondary education. Targeted marginalised girls who are supported to enrol in secondary education learn useful knowledge and skills.

Remove economic barriers that prevent girls marginalised by early marriage, domestic labour, risky child migration and/or street-living to enrol and stay longer in vocational education. Targeted marginalised girls who are supported to enrol in vocational education learn useful knowledge and skills.
